{{Chembox | Watchedfields = changed | ImageFile = dicarbon.svg | ImageSize = 120px | IUPACName = Diatomic carbon | SystematicName = Ethenediylidene (substitutive)
Dicarbon(''C''—''C'') (additive) |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo = 12070-15-4 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|changed|??}} | PubChem = 139247 | ChemSpiderID = 122807 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChEBI = 30083 | Gmelin = 196 | SMILES = [C]=[C] | StdInChI = 1S/C2/c1-2 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = LBVWYGNGGJURHQ-UHFFFAOYSA-N | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | C=2 }} }} '''Diatomic carbon''' (systematically named '''dicarbon''' and '''1λ2,2λ2-ethene''', is a green, gaseous [[inorganic chemistry|inorganic]] [[chemical]] with the [[chemical formula]] C=C (also written {{Chem|[C|2|]}} or {{Chem|C|2}}). It is kinetically unstable at ambient temperature and pressure, being removed through autopolymerisation. It occurs in carbon vapor, for example in [[electric arc]]s; in [[comet]]s, [[stellar atmosphere]]s and the [[interstellar medium]]; and in blue [[hydrocarbon]] [[flame]]s.{{cite journal | first = Roald | last = Hoffmann | authorlink = Roald Hoffmann | title = Marginalia: C2 In All Its Guises | journal = [[American Scientist]] | year = 1995 | url = http://www.roaldhoffmann.com/sites/all/files/c2_in_all-_its_guises.pdf | volume = 83 | issue = 4 | pages = 309–311 | bibcode = 1995AmSci..83..309H | jstor = 29775475}} Diatomic carbon is the second simplest form of carbon after [[atomic carbon]], and is an intermediate participator in the genesis of fullerenes. == Properties == C2 is a component of carbon vapor. One paper estimates that carbon vapor is around 28% diatomic, but theoretically this depends on the temperature and pressure. === Electromagnetic properties === The electrons in diatomic carbon are distributed among the atomic orbitals according to the aufbau principle to produce unique quantum states, with corresponding energy levels. The state with the lowest energy level, or ground state, is a singlet state (1Σ{{Su|b=''g''|p=+}}), which is systematically named ethene-1,2-diylidene or dicarbon(0•). There are several excited singlet and triplet states that are relatively close in energy to the ground state, which form significant proportions of a sample of dicarbon under ambient conditions. When most of these excited states undergo photochemical relaxation, they emmit in the infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum. However, one state in particular emmits in the green region. That state is a triplet state (3Π''g''), which is systematically named ethene-μ,μ-diyl-μ-ylidene or dicarbon(2•). In addition, there is an excited state somewhat further in energy from the ground state, which only form a significant proportion of a sample of dicarbon under mid-ultraviolet irradiation. Upon relaxation, this excited state fluoresces in the violet region and phosphoresces in the blue region. This state is also a singlet state (1Π''g''), which is also named ethene-μ,μ-diyl-μ-ylidene or dicarbon(2•). {| class="wikitable" |- ! State !! Excitation

Blue |} [[Molecular orbital theory]] shows that there are two sets of paired electrons in a degenerate pi bonding set of orbitals. This gives a bond order of 2, meaning that there should exist a double bond between the two carbons in a C2 molecule. One analysis suggests instead that a [[quadruple bond]] exists,{{cite journal | title = Quadruple bonding in C2 and analogous eight-valence electron species | first1 = Sason | last1 = Shaik | first2 = David | last2 = Danovich | first3 = Wei | last3 = Wu | first4 = Peifeng | last4 = Su | first5 = Henry S. | last5 = Rzepa | authorlink5 = Henry Rzepa | first6 = Philippe C. | last6 = Hiberty | journal = [[Nature Chemistry]] | year = 2012 | volume = 4 | issue = 3 | pages = 195–200 | doi = 10.1038/nchem.1263 | bibcode = 2012NatCh...4..195S }} an interpretation that was disputed.{{cite journal | title = Quantum chemistry: Quadruply bonded carbon | first = Jörg | last = Grunenberg | journal = [[Nature Chemistry]] | year = 2012 | volume = 4 | issue = 3 | pages = 154–155 | doi = 10.1038/nchem.1274 | bibcode = 2012NatCh...4..154G}} [[CASSCF]] calculations indicate that the quadruple bond based on molecular orbital theory is also reasonable.{{cite journal|title = Latent harmony in dicarbon between VB and MO theories through orthogonal hybridization of 3σg and 2σu|first1 = Ronglin|last1 = Zhong|first2 = Min|last2 = Zhang|first3 = Hongliang|last3 = Xu|first4 = Zhongmin|last4 = Su|journal = [[Chemical Science (journal)|Chemical Science]]|year = 2016|volume = 7|pages = 1028–1032|doi = 10.1039/c5sc03437j}} [[Bond dissociation energy|Bond dissociation energies]] of [[Boron|B2]], C2, and [[Nitrogen|N2]] show increasing BDE, indicating single, double, and triple bonds, respectively. In certain forms of crystalline carbon, such as diamond and graphite, a saddle point or “hump” occurs at the bond site in the charge density. The triplet state of C2 does follow this trend. However, the singlet state of C2 acts more like silicon or germanium; that is, the charge density has a maximum at the bond site.{{cite journal | title = Higher-order finite-difference pseudopotential method: An application to diatomic molecules | last1 = Chelikowsky | first1 = James R. | authorlink1 = James R. Chelikowsky | last2 = Troullier | first2 = N. | last3 = Wu | first3 = K. | last4 = Saad | first4 = Y. | journal = [[Physical Review B]] | year = 1994 | volume = 50 | pages = 11356–11364 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.50.11355 | bibcode = 1994PhRvB..5011355C}} == Reactions == Diatomic carbon will react with [[acetone]] and [[acetaldehyde]] to produce [[acetylene]] by two different pathways.{{cite journal | title = Chemistry of the singlet and triplet C2 molecules. Mechanism of acetylene formation from reaction with acetone and acetaldehyde | first1 = Philip S. | last1 = Skell | authorlink = Philip Skell | first2 = James H. | last2 = Plonka | journal = [[Journal of the American Chemical Society]] | year = 1970 | volume = 92 | issue = 19 | pages = 5620–5624| doi = 10.1021/ja00722a014}} * [[Triplet state|Triplet]] C2 molecules will react through an intermolecular pathway, which is shown to exhibit radical character. The intermediate for this pathway is the ethylene radical. Its abstraction is correlated with bond energies. * [[Singlet state|Singlet]] C2 molecules will react through an intramolecular, nonradical pathway in which two hydrogen atoms will be taken away from one molecule. The intermediate for this pathway is singlet [[vinylidene]]. The singlet reaction can happen through a 1,1-diabstraction or a 1,2-diabstraction. This reaction is insensitive to isotope substitution. The different abstractions are possibly due to the spatial orientations of the collisions rather than the bond energies. * Singlet C2 will also react with [[alkene]]s. Acetylene is a major product; however, it appears C2 will insert into carbon-hydrogen bonds. * C2 is 2.5 times more likely to insert into a [[methyl group]] as into [[methylene group]]s.{{cite journal | title = Reaction of Diatomic Carbon with Alkanes and Ethers/ Trapping of Alkylcarbenes by Vinylidene | last1 = Skell | first1 = P. S. | authorlink1 = Philip Skell | last2 = Fagone | first2 = F. A. | last3 = Klabunde | first3 = K. J. | journal = [[Journal of the American Chemical Society]] | year = 1972 | volume = 94 | issue = 22 | pages = 7862–7866| doi = 10.1021/ja00777a032}} == History == [[File:C2014Q2 Lovejoy by Paul Stewart.png|thumb|C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy) glows green due to diatomic carbon.]] The light of fainter comets mainly originates from the emission of diatomic carbon. An example is [[C/2014 Q2 (Lovejoy)]], where there are several lines of C2 light, mostly in the [[visible spectrum]], forming the [[Swan band]]s.{{cite journal | url = http://www.observatorij.org/CCDPhot/iwca5.html | first1 = Herman | last1 = Mikuz | first2 = Bojan | last2 = Dintinjana | title = CCD Photometry of Comets | journal = [[International Comet Quarterly]] | year = 1994 | accessdate = October 26, 2006}} {{Clear}} ==See also== * [[Acetylide]] - a related chemical with the formula C22− == References == {{reflist}} {{allotropes of carbon}} {{diatomicelements}} {{Molecules detected in outer space}} [[Category:Astrochemistry]] [[Category:Carbon forms]] [[Category:Homonuclear diatomic molecules]]

'''Girl Develop It''' (GDI) is a nonprofit organization devoted to getting women the materials they need to pursue careers in [[software development]]. It provides affordable programs for adult women interested in learning web and software development in a judgment-free environment.<ref name=":0" /> Their mission is to give women of any income level, nationality, education level, and upbringing an environment in which to learn the skills to build websites and learn [[Source code|code]] to build programs with hands-on classes in two countries in 56 cities.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |url= https://www.girldevelopit.com/about |title= About - Girl Develop It |website= www.girldevelopit.com |language= en-US |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.fastcompany.com/3027199/fast-feed/this-coding-school-is-offering-scholarships-to-women-who-want-to-be-developers |title= This Coding School Is Offering Scholarships To Women Who Want To Be Developers |date= 2014-03-06 |newspaper= Fast Company |language= en-US|access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/article128887384.html |title= How Triangle towns aim to make government more transparent and accessible |newspaper= Newsobserver |language= en |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.phillyvoice.com/girl-develop-its-new-co-leader-self-taught/ |title= Girl Develop It's new co-leader is self-taught tech engineer |newspaper= PhillyVoice |access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news |url= http://www.wgrz.com/news/local/girls-gather-to-code-at-all-women-hackathon/351355011 |title= Girls gather to code at all-women Hackathon |last=TEGNA |newspaper=WGRZ |language=en-US |access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref><ref name="The Editorial Board 2017">{{cite web |author= The Editorial Board |title= Triangle cities, towns open doors to data |website= newsobserver |date= January 31, 2017 |url= http://www.newsobserver.com/opinion/editorials/article129907124.html |accessdate= February 3, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Locations>{{Cite web |url= https://www.girldevelopit.com/chapters |title= We are Now in 56 Cities! |access-date= 2017-03-10}}</ref>
==History== Girl Develop It was started in 2010 by Vanessa Hurst and Sara Chipps<ref name="Shattuck 2010">{{cite web |last= Shattuck |first= Justin |title= Herding Code 90: Sara Chipps on Girl Develop IT and Girls Developing Software |website= Herding Code |date= August 12, 2010 |url= http://herdingcode.com/herding-code-90-sara-chipps-on-girl-develop-it-and-girls-developing-software/ |accessdate= February 3, 2017}}</ref> with their flagship location in [[New York City]]. GDI started with just one class that sold out in one day. Today more than 55,000 members have been helped. Between that, they have built up their organization to 53 cities<ref name="Deng 2017">{{cite web |last=Deng |first=Olivia |title= 'Don't Be Shy, Develop It!' Girl Develop It Empowers Women in Technology |website= The Huffington Post |date= January 9, 2017 |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/olivia-deng/dont-be-shy-develop-it-gi_1_b_14011232.html |accessdate= February 3, 2017}}</ref> in 33 states and districts in the [[United States]]<ref name=Locations/> and one in [[Ottawa|Ottawa, Ontario Canada]]. Recently, Girl Develop It has empowered more than 1,000 students per month with coding skills. <ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.girldevelopit.com/donate | title= gdi-Help Us Change the World |access-date= 2017-03-10}}</ref>In late 2017, GDI will start addressing international inquiries.<ref name=":0" /> The organization and local chapters have hosted or participated in [[hackathon]]<nowiki/>s. During the [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] chapter's second event in 2016, developers competed to create [[website]]s for nonprofit woman- and minority-owned organizations.<ref name=":1" /> The organization has also hosted hackathons in [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]],<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.philly.com/philly/news/new_jersey/20160125_A_hack-athon_for_Camden_focuses_on_violence.html |title= A hack-athon for Camden focuses on violence |newspaper= Philly.com |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref> in [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://technical.ly/delaware/2016/11/30/girl-develop-it-east-coast-regional-hackathon/ |title= Girl Develop It is hosting its first East Coast regional hackathon in Wilmington - Technical.ly Delaware |date= 2016-11-30 |newspaper= Technical.ly Delaware |language= en-US |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref> and in [[Seattle]].<ref name=":2" />
== Chapters == {| class="wikitable" |+Locations of GDI Chapters<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.girldevelopit.com/chapters |title= Chapters - Girl Develop It |website= www.girldevelopit.com |language= en-US |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref> !State !City |- |'''Arizona''' |Phoenix<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://arizonaexperience.org/azscitech-blog?page=4 |title= Arizona SciTech Blog {{!}} The Arizona Experience - landscapes, people, culture and events |website= arizonaexperience.org |language= en |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref> |- |'''California''' |{{unbulleted list|Los Angeles<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.builtinla.com/2014/08/20/5-la-organizations-will-teach-you-code-free |title= 5 LA organizations that will teach you to code for free |website= Built In Los Angeles |access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>||Oakland|Orange County<ref name=Locations/>|San Diego|San Francisco<ref name=":3">{{Cite news |url= http://www.sfgate.com/technology/article/Women-take-future-of-coding-in-own-hands-4204113.php |title= Women take future of coding in own hands |newspaper= SFGate |access-date= 2017-02-03}}</ref>|San Jose}} |- |'''Colorado''' |{{unbulleted list|Boulder|Denver|Fort Collins}}|Boulder/Denver<ref name=Locations/>

== Curriculum == Girl Develop It (GDI) offers materials on their website that are licensed under a [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0)]] license and that provide visitors with tools and resources to [[Web development|develop]] online. The curriculum is [[Web hosting service|hosted]] and constructed by the GDI community on the web-based [[Repository (version control)|version control repository]] [[GitHub]] and presented in a slide format, divided by topic. On the GitHub curriculum page, materials are broken up in a color coded format that shows whether they have been reviewed by other members of the community or if the topics meet the requirements or recommendations of the curriculum. These materials are accessible by anyone on the Internet but Girl Development offers in-person courses and social communities at established chapters.
The topics of the curriculum include: * Web Concepts * Beginner and Intermediate level [[HTML]] and [[Cascading Style Sheets|CSS]] * Beginner [[JavaScript]] * Beginner [[AngularJS|Angular.js]] * Web Accessibility * Beginner [[PHP]]/[[MySQL]] * Beginner [[GitHub]] Usage
== Founders ==
=== Vanessa Hurst === Hurst is a [[computer programmer]], [[social entrepreneur]], teacher,<ref name=":0"/> and lifetime [[Girl Scouts of the USA|girl scout]], and a co-founder of Girl Develop It. In 2013 she launched the CodeMontage platform. She is also responsible for founding and running Developers For Good and also NYC-based Network of Technologists. She is a strong advocator for computing, software, and coding for everyone. She is currently based in [[New York City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vanessahurst.com/about|title=About|website=vanessahurst.com|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>
=== Sara Chipps === Chipps is a [[JavaScript]] developer and co-founder of Girl Develop It. Once the [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] of Flatiron School,<ref name="crunchböase 2016">{{cite web | title=Sara Chipps - Chief Technology Officer @ Flatiron School | website=crunchbase | date=December 28, 2016 | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/sara-chipps | accessdate=February 3, 2017}}</ref> she is currently the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of Jewelbots, a friendship bracelet that helps children learn to code. She is currently based in [[New York City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sarajchipps.com/about|title=About|website=sarajchipps.com|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref>
== Current Leaders ==
=== Corinne Warnshuis, Executive Director === Corinne has previously held positions with the Technical.ly news network, producing large-scale technology conferences like Philly Tech Week and Baltimore Innovation Week. <ref name=":0"/>
=== Vanessa Hurst, Co-Founder, Advisor === Vanessa is a lifetime Girl Scout, a teacher, and a passionate supporter of open source software. She also founded organizes Developers for Good. <ref name=":0"/>
=== Bindu Jallabah, Operations Director === Prior to joining GDI, Bindu won awards for her work developing and executing the operational strategy for the Elwyn Baring Street Center. Bindu is also founder and Board Chair of Karanso Africa.<ref name=":0"/>
== Supporters == Girl Develop It (GDI) lists numerous companies and organizations on their website that have backed, partnered with, or supported them and their cause.
Notable Supporters include: * [[AOL|American Online (AOL)]] * [[Black Girls Code|Black Girls CODE]] * [[Bold is Beautiful Project]] * [[CodeMontage]] * [[Craigslist]] * [[DuckDuckGo]] * [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation|Knight Foundation]] * [[Salesforce.com|Salesforce]] * Sticker Mule * [[Qualcomm]]

A '''gravel stop''' is a sheet metal fabrication used at the perimeter of [[flat roof|built up roofing]].
== Background == Traditional [[flat roof|built up roofing]] (informally called '''"tar-and-gravel" roofing''') consists of multiple layers of [[roofing felt]] mopped with layers of hot liquid [[bitumen]], and surfaced with [[gravel]]. At the edges of the roof, some means is required of terminating the roofing, preventing water from running underneath the roofing, and preventing the gravel surfacing from washing off in heavy rains. The traditional method is a sheet metal fabrication called a gravel stop.
== Materials == Gravel stops are made from sheet metals including [[copper]], [[aluminum]], [[terne]] metal, [[galvanized]] steel, and [[stainless steel]].
== References == ''Architectural Sheet Metal Manual'', 6th Edition, Sheet Metal and Air Conditioning Contractors National Association (SMACNA), 2003

{{Infobox university | name = Henan Agricultural University | native_name = 河南农业大学 | native_name_lang = zh-hans | image_name = | image_size = 160px | motto = | mottoeng = | established = 1912 | type = [[National university|National]] | city = [[Zhengzhou]] | country = {{PRC}} | website = [http://www.henau.edu.cn www.henau.edu.cn] | logo = | footnotes = }} '''Henan Agricultural University''' ({{zh|c=河南农业大学|p=Hénán Nóngyè Dàxué}}) is a public university in [[Zhengzhou]], [[Henan]], [[China]]. It was established in 1912 under the name Henan Public Agricultural Major School. The school area is approximately 144000 square meters.
The university has established intercollegiate ties with universities in the United Kingdom, United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Thailand, the Netherlands and other countries.<ref>http://www.rau.ac.uk/news/college-news/henan-agricultural-university-celebrates-100-years</ref><ref name=csc-edu>{{cite web|title=Henan Agricultural University - Study In China|url=http://www.csc.edu.cn/laihua/universitydetailen.aspx?collegeId=273|publisher=csc.edu.cn|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=admissions-cn>{{cite web|title=Study in Henan Agricultural University|url=http://www.admissions.cn/henau/|publisher=admissions.cn|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=inchina>{{cite web|title=Henan Agricultural University (HAU) |url=http://www.inchina.cc/home/studyinchina/user/henau/en/Default.htm |publisher=inchina.cc |accessdate=20 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320232137/http://www.inchina.cc/home/studyinchina/user/henau/en/Default.htm |archivedate=20 March 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref name=chinauniversity-info>{{cite web|title=University in Henan - China's University Guide|url=http://www.chinauniversity.info/2009/11/henan-agricultural-university.html|publisher=chinauniversity.info|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref>
==Academics== The university consists of 10 departments: [[Agricultural]], [[Engineering]], [[Management]], [[Economics]], [[Laws]], [[Science]], [[Arts]], [[Education]], [[Medical Science]], Musical Art. It is equipped with 20 colleges.
The university has level 1st, level 2nd and national key discipline, 34 provincial key disciplines, six postdoctoral research bachelors, five level 1st Ph.D. degree authorization subjects, 28 Ph.D. points, 18 level 1st master's degree authorization subjects, 73 master's degree programs, and 54 degree courses.
A national wheat engineering technology research center, national corn improvement ([[zhengzhou]]) branch, the national tobacco cultivation physiological and biochemical research base on 24 national and provincial research center and the key laboratory. Strong professors, more than 1700 teaching staff currently, including 11 double-hired academicians, more than 400 professors and associate professors, three 1st and 2nd level experts of national “key talent project”, the experts obtain ‘Chinese agriculture talent award’, four national outstanding contribution young and middle-age experts, 34 people have special allowance from the state council of China, two national key teachers, 11 provincial class doctors, 34 province administrating outstanding experts, seven provincial innovative talents, 29 provincial academic technology leaders, and 68 provincial key teachers.
==Collaboration with the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center== In January 2017, Henan Agricultural University and the [[International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center]] (CIMMYT, Texcoco, Mexico) signed a long-term collaborative agreement which will expand on the knowledge and capacities of each institution by setting up shared research programs in these important row crops.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cimmyt.org/press_release/china-launches-new-cimmyt-henan-agricultural-university-joint-maize-and-wheat-research-center/ |title=China launches new CIMMYT-Henan Agricultural University joint maize and wheat research center |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=January 11, 2017 |website=www.cimmyt.org |publisher=CIMMYT |access-date=June 13, 2017 |quote=The center was officially initiated with an agreement signed between the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT) and Henan Agricultural University (HAU)}}</ref> Scientists from CIMMYT and the university will collaborate and publish in a new state-of-the-art research center, benefiting the world of agricultural research as well as the smallholder farmer in wheat and maize growing regions around the world.
Henan Province produces over 6 million hectares of wheat and over 3 million hectares of maize, equating to more than 25% of China's wheat production and 10% of its maize. The CIMMYT collaboration will focus on scientist training and research as well as technological innovation in the plant sciences.
==Campus, art and culture== The campus of Henan Agricultural University is at center of [[Zhengzhou]], the area is approximately 144000㎡. The design is made of themed parks on each side of campus. The design makes a good use of the [[drainage|drainage system]] and the natural environment; it makes students to have a better life in the campus.
==International students== The school started to receive foreign students in 1987. To enable the foreign students to better adapt to university's life, they can start special courses as soon as possible. International Education College of Henan Agricultural University set up a Chinese training program in 2004. They have created a good environment and opportunities to study Chinese and understand Chinese culture.

[[Image:J-Dryden.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[John Dryden]], who formulated and wrote the heroic drama in the 1670s.]] '''Heroic drama''' is a type of [[Play (theatre)|play]] popular during the [[English Restoration|Restoration]] era in [[England]], distinguished by both its verse structure and its subject matter.<ref>Eugene M. Waith, ''Ideas of Greatness: Heroic Drama in England'', London, Routledge, 1971.</ref><ref>John Douglas Canfield, ''Heroes and States: On the Ideology of Restoration Tragedy'', Lexington, KY, University Press of Kentucky, 2000.</ref> The subgenre of heroic drama evolved through several works of the middle to later 1660s; [[John Dryden]]'s ''[[The Indian Emperour]]'' ([[1665 in literature|1665]]) and [[Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery| Roger Boyle's]] ''[[The Black Prince (play)|The Black Prince]]'' ([[1667 in literature|1667]]) were key developments.
==Dryden in 1670== The term "heroic drama" was invented by Dryden for his play, ''[[The Conquest of Granada]]'' ([[1670 in literature|1670]]). For the ''Preface'' to the printed version of the play, Dryden argued that the drama was a species of ''[[epic poetry]]'' for the stage, that, as the epic was to other poetry, so the heroic drama was to other plays. Consequently, Dryden derived a series of rules for this type of play.
First, the play should be composed in [[heroic verse]] (closed couplets in iambic pentameter). Second, the play must focus on a subject that pertains to national foundations, mythological events, or important and grand matters. Third, the hero of the heroic drama must be powerful, decisive, and, like [[Achilles]], dominating even when wrong. ''The Conquest of Granada'' followed all of these rules. The story was that of the national foundation of [[Spain]] (and [[Charles II of England|King Charles II]] was known to be fond of Spanish plays), and the hero, Almanzor, was a man of great martial prowess and temperament.
Dryden's ''Conquest of Granada'' is often considered one of the better heroic tragedies, but his highest achievement is his adaptation (which he called ''All for Love'', 1678) of Shakespeare's ''Anthony and Cleopatra'' to the heroic formula. Other heroic dramatists were Nathaniel Lee (''The Rival Queens'') and Thomas Otway, whose ''Venice Preserved'' is a fine tragedy that transcends the usual limitations of the form. We also owe indirectly to heroic tragedy two very amusing parodies of the type: the Duke of Buckingham's ''The Rehearsal'' and Henry Fielding's ''The Tragedy of Tragedies, or the Life and Death of Tom Thumb the Great''
==Other dramatists== "Those who associate 'heroic drama' primarily with the use of the 'heroic couplet' usually set as its extent the years from 1664 to 1678. This, certainly, is its period of fullest development and authority. Those who prefer to accentuate the elements suggested by the very term 'heroic' rather than the strict rhymed verse form are willing to admit wider limits."<ref>George Henry Nettleton, ''English Drama of the Restoration and Eighteenth Century, 1642–1780'', New York, Macmillan, 1914; p. 23.</ref> Restoration plays by Sir [[William Davenant]], [[Thomas Otway]], [[Nathaniel Lee]], [[John Crowne]], [[Elkanah Settle]], and [[John Banks (playwright)|John Banks]], and later works by [[Nicholas Rowe (writer)|Nicholas Rowe]] and [[Joseph Addison]], have been included in tighter or looser definitions of heroic drama.<ref>Nettleton, pp. 24-9; Waith, pp. 235-86.</ref>
==Heroic drama in literary criticism== Today, drama is divided up into numerous subgenres; Dryden, however, worked from [[Classical literature|Classical]] critics. There was little dramatic critical theory for him to appeal to, and the new rules brought over from [[France]] (particularly those of [[Pierre Corneille|Corneille]] and [[Nicolas Boileau-Despréaux|Boileau]]) did not match English theatrical history or practice. The emphasis on unities and on maintaining only Classically proscribed dramatic forms also came from [[Thomas Rymer]], who condemned the heterogeneity of the stage. [[Aristotle]] had only spoken of [[satire]], [[Epic poetry|epic]], and [[tragedy]], and [[Horace]] also wrote only of [[comedy]], tragedy and satire, and so Dryden was seeking to square actual theatrical practice with an ancient framework for literature. He was attempting his own neo-classicism. The [[First Folio]] of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] had divided Shakespeare's plays into "history," "tragedy," and "comedy," but these terms were stretched. Dryden, therefore, implicitly recognizes that drama had moved into the territory of other types of poetry, but he strives to restrain that freedom by reforming the stage to a true and epic subject matter.
==Satirical response== [[George Villiers, 2nd Duke of Buckingham]] and others satirized heroic drama in ''[[The Rehearsal (play)|The Rehearsal]]''. The satire was successful enough that heroic drama largely disappeared afterward. Buckingham attacked the stupidity of blustering, military heroes, as well as the apparent self-importance of attempting a dramatic entertainment about the serious subjects of military and national history.
Buckingham's criticism of Dryden in ''[[The Rehearsal (play)|The Rehearsal]]'' is partly Dryden's bombastic verse but, more pointedly, Dryden's ''personal'' interest in creating a "pure" drama. The character of Bayes is ludicrous more for his hubris in damning actual plays in favor of imagined ones than he is for being a poetaster.

{{more footnotes|date=September 2015}}'''Heterogram''' ([[classical compound]]: "[[wikt:hetero-#English|different]]" + "[[wikt:-gram#English|written]]") is a term used mostly in the [[philology|study of ancient texts]] for a special kind of a [[logogram]] consisting of the embedded written representation of a word in a foreign language, which does not have a spoken counterpart in the main (matrix) language of the text. In most cases, the matrix and embedded languages share the same script. While from the perspective of the embedded language the word may be written either phonetically (representing the sounds of the embedded language) or logographically, it is never a phonetic spelling from the point of view of the matrix language of the text, since there is no relationship between the symbols used and the underlying pronunciation of the word in the matrix language.
In English, the written abbreviations ''[[wikt:e.g.|e.g.]]'', ''[[wikt:i.e.|i.e.]]'', and ''[[wikt:viz.|viz.]]'' are often read respectively as "for example", "that is", and "namely". When read this way, the abbreviations for the [[Latin]] words ''exempli gratia'', ''id est'', and ''videlicet'' are being used logographically to indicate unrelated English phrases. Similarly, the [[ampersand]] ⟨&⟩, originally a [[typographic ligature|ligature]] for the Latin word ''[[wikt:et#Latin|et]]'', in many European languages stands logographically for the local word for "and" regardless of pronunciation. This can be contrasted with the older way of abbreviating ''[[et cetera]]''—''[[wikt:&c.|&c.]]''—where ⟨&⟩ is used to represent ''et'' as a full [[loanword]], not a heterogram.
Heterograms are frequent in [[cuneiform script]]s, such as the [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] cuneiform, which uses [[Cuneiform script|Sumerian]] heterograms, or the Anatolian cuneiform, which uses both [[Cuneiform script|Sumerian]] and [[Cuneiform script|Akkadian]] heterograms.<ref>Kudrinski M. and I. Yakubovich. 2016. Sumerograms and Akkadograms in Hittite: Ideograms, Logograms, Allograms, or Heterograms? ''Altorientalische Forschungen'' 43(1-2): 53-66.</ref> In [[Middle Iranian languages|Middle Iranian]] scripts derived from the [[Aramaic]] scripts (such as the [[Pahlavi scripts]]), all logograms are heterograms coming from Aramaic.<ref>Encyclopedia Iranica, [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/huzwares Huswāreš].</ref> Sometimes such heterograms are referred to by terms identifying the source language such as "[[Sumerogram]]s" or "[[Aramaeogram]]s".
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Heterotopia in the work of other authors */
revision.text:
'''Heterotopia''' is a concept elaborated by philosopher [[Michel Foucault]] to describe certain cultural, institutional and discursive spaces that are somehow ‘other’: disturbing, intense, incompatible, contradictory or transforming. Heterotopias are worlds within worlds, mirroring and yet upsetting what is outside. Foucault provides examples: ships, cemeteries, brothels, prisons, gardens of antiquity, fairs, Turkish baths and many more. Foucault outlines the notion of heterotopia on three occasions between 1966-67. A [https://foucault.info/documents/heterotopia/foucault.heteroTopia.en/ talk] given to a group of architects is the most well-known explanation of the term. His first mention of the concept is in his ''preface'' to 'The Order of Things' and refers to texts rather than socio-cultural spaces.<ref>{{cite book |last=Foucault |first=Michel |date=1971 |title=The Order of Things |location=New York |publisher=Vintage Books |isbn=978-0-679-75335-3}}</ref>
==Etymology== Heterotopia follows the template established by the notions of [[utopia]] and [[dystopia]]. The prefix hetero- is from Ancient Greek ἕτερος (héteros, "other, another, different") and is combined with the Greek morpheme τόπος ("place") and means "other place". A utopia is an idea or an image that is not real but represents a perfected version of society, such as [[Utopia (book)|Thomas More's book]] or [[Le Corbusier]]'s drawings. As Walter Russell Mead has written, "Utopia is a place where everything is good; dystopia is a place where everything is bad; heterotopia is where things are different — that is, a collection whose members have few or no intelligible connections with one another."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mead |first=Walter Russell |date=Winter 1995–1996 |title=Trains, Planes, and Automobiles: The End of the Postmodern Moment |url= |journal=World Policy Journal |volume=12 |issue=4 |pages=13–31 |jstor=40209444}}</ref>
==Heterotopia in Foucault== Foucault uses the term "heterotopia" ({{lang-fr|hétérotopie}}) to describe spaces that have more layers of meaning or relationships to other places than immediately meet the eye. In general, a heterotopia is a physical representation or approximation of a utopia, or a parallel space (such as a prison) that contains undesirable bodies to make a real utopian space impossible.
Foucault explains the link between utopias and heterotopias using the metaphor of a mirror. A mirror is a utopia because the image reflected is a 'placeless place', an unreal virtual place that allows one to see one's own visibility. However, the mirror is also a heterotopia, in that it is a real object. The heterotopia of the mirror is at once absolutely real, relating with the real space surrounding it, and absolutely unreal, creating a virtual image.
Foucault articulates several possible types of heterotopia or spaces that exhibit dual meanings: * A ‘crisis heterotopia’ is a separate space like a boarding school or a motel room where activities like coming of age or a honeymoon take place out of sight. Foucault describes the crisis heterotopia as "reserved for individuals who are, in relation to society and to the human environment in which they live, in a state of crisis." He also points that crisis heterotopias are constantly disappearing from society and being replaced by the following heterotopia of deviation. * ‘Heterotopias of deviation’ are institutions where we place individuals whose behavior is outside the norm (hospitals, asylums, prisons, rest homes, cemetery). * Heterotopia can be a single real place that juxtaposes several spaces. A garden can be a heterotopia, if it is a real space meant to be a microcosm of different environments, with plants from around the world. * 'Heterotopias of time' such as museums enclose in one place objects from all times and styles. They exist in time but also exist outside of time because they are built and preserved to be physically insusceptible to time’s ravages. * 'Heterotopias of ritual or purification' are spaces that are isolated and penetrable yet not freely accessible like a public place. Either entry to the heterotopia is compulsory like in entering a prison, or entry requires special rituals or gestures, like in a [[sauna]] or a [[Turkish bath|hammam]]. * Heterotopia has a function in relation to all of the remaining spaces. The two functions are: heterotopia of illusion creates a space of illusion that exposes every real space, and the heterotopia of compensation is to create a real space—a space that is other.
Foucault's elaborations on heterotopias were published in an article entitled ''Des espaces autres'' (Of Other Spaces). The philosopher calls for a society with many heterotopias, not only as a space with several places of/for the affirmation of difference, but also as a means of escape from authoritarianism and repression, stating metaphorically that if we take the ship as the utmost heterotopia, a society without ships is inherently a repressive one, in a clear reference to [[Stalinism]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Foucault |first=Michel |date=October 1984 |title=Des Espace Autres |journal=Architecture, Mouvement, Continuité |volume=5 |pages=46–49}}; it has been translated into English twice, first as {{cite journal |last=Foucault |first=Michel |others=trans. Jay Miskowiec |date=Spring 1986 |title=Of Other Spaces |journal=Diacritics |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=22–27}} available online at [http://foucault.info/documents/heterotopia/foucault.heterotopia.en.html foucault.info] (accessed 10 August 2014); and second as {{cite book |last=Foucault |first=Michel |editor-first=James D. |editor-last=Faubion |others=trans. Robert Hurley |title=Aesthetics, Method, and Epistemology: Essential Works of Foucault, 1954-1984, Volume 2 |location=New York |publisher=The New Press |date=1998 |pages=175–185 |chapter=Different Spaces |isbn=978-1565843295}}; ambiguities of the two translations are discussed in {{cite journal |last=Johnson |first=Peter |date=November 2006 |title=Unravelling Foucault's 'Different Spaces' |journal=History of the Human Sciences |publisher=SAGE |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=75–90 |doi=10.1177/0952695106069669}}.</ref>
==Heterotopia in the work of other authors== Human geographers often connected to the [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] school have been using the term (and the author's propositions) to help understand the contemporary emergence of (cultural, social, political, economic) difference and identity as a central issue in larger multicultural cities. The idea of ''place'' (more often related to ethnicity and gender and less often to the social class issue) as a heterotopic entity has been gaining attention in the current context of postmodern, post-structuralist theoretical discussion (and political practice) in Geography and other spatial social sciences. The concept of a heterotopia has also been discussed in relation to the space in which learning takes place.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Blair |first=Erik |date=2009 |title=A Further Education College as a Heterotopia |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13596740902717465 |journal=Research in Post-Compulsory Education |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=93–101 |doi=10.1080/13596740902717465}}</ref> There is an extensive debate with theorists, such as [[David Harvey]], that remain focused on the matter of class domination as the central determinant of social heteronomy.
The geographer [[Edward Soja]] has worked with this concept in dialogue with the works of [[Henri Lefebvre]] concerning urban space in the book ''Thirdspace''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Soja |first=Edward |date=1996 |title=Thirdspace: Journeys to Los Angeles and Other Real-and-Imagined Places |location=Malden, Mass. |publisher=Blackwell Publishers |isbn=1-55786-675-9 }}</ref>
Mary Franklin-Brown uses the concept of heterotopia in an epistemological context to examine the thirteenth century [[encyclopedia|encyclopedias]] of [[Vincent of Beauvais]] and [[Ramon Llull]] as conceptual spaces where many possible ways of knowing are brought together without attempting to reconcile them.<ref>{{cite book |last=Franklin-Brown |first=Mary |date=2012 |title=Reading the World: Encyclopedic Writing in the Scholastic Age |location=Chicago, Ill. |publisher=University Of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-26068-6}}</ref>
New Media scholar Hye Jean Chung applies the concept of heterotopia to describe the multiple superimposed layers of spaciality and temporality observed in highly digitized audiovisual media. A heterotopic perception of digital media is, according to Chung, to grasp the globally dispersed labor structure of multinational capitalism that produces the audiovisual representations of various spacio-temporalities. <ref>Chung, Hye Jean. ''Media Heterotopias: Digital Effects and Material Labor in Global Film Production'', Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2018, pp.17-37 </ref>
==Heterotopia in literature== The concept of heterotopia has had a significant impact on literature, especially science fiction, fantasy and other [[Speculative fiction|speculative genres]]. Many readers consider the worlds of [[China Miéville]] and other [[weird fiction]] writers to be heterotopias insofar as they are worlds of radical difference transparent or of indifference to their inhabitants.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Gordon |first=Joan |date=November 2003 |title=Hybridity, Heterotopia, and Mateship in China Miéville's ''Perdido Street Station'' |journal=Science Fiction Studies |publisher=SF-TH Inc., DePauw University |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=456–476 |jstor=4241204}}</ref> [[Samuel R. Delany|Samuel Delany's]] 1976 novel ''[[Triton (novel)|Trouble on Triton]]'' is subtitled ''An Ambiguous Heterotopia'' and was written partly in dialogue with [[Ursula K. Le Guin|Ursula K. Le Guin's]] science fiction novel ''[[The Dispossessed]]'', which is subtitled ''An Ambiguous Utopia''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Delany |first=Samuel R. |date=November 1990 |title=On ''Triton'' and Other Matters: An Interview with Samuel R. Delany |url=http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/interviews/delany52interview.htm |journal=Science Fiction Studies |publisher=SF-TH Inc., DePauw University |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=295–324 |jstor=4240009}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Chan |first=Edward K. |date=Summer 2001 |title=(Vulgar) Identity Politics in Outer Space: Delany's ''Triton'' and the Heterotopian Narrative |journal=Journal of Narrative Theory |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=180–213 |jstor=30225762}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |editor1-last=Dehaene |editor1-first=Michiel |editor2-last=De Cauter |editor2-first=Lieven |date=2008 |title=Heterotopia and the City: Public Space in a Postcivil Society |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0-415-42288-8}} * {{cite book |last=Preucel |first=Robert W. |last2=Matero |first2=Frank G. |editor-first=Patricia E. |editor-last=Rubertone |title=Archaeologies of Placemaking: Monuments, Memories, and Engagement in Native North America |publisher=Left Coast Press |date=2008 |pages=81–99 |chapter=Placemaking on the Northern Rio Grande: A View from Kuaua Pueblo |url=http://repository.upenn.edu/hp_papers/15/ |isbn=978-1598741551}}
==External links== * [http://www.heterotopiastudies.com/ Heterotopian Studies] is a website devoted to exploring Foucault's ideas on heterotopia. Run by Dr Peter Johnson, the site contains (1) on-going bibliographies listing hundreds of articles that engage with the concept of heterotopia (b) links to artists who have explored the notion and (3) a blog updating resources and publications.

{{Use British English|date=October 2016}} '''High-altitude adaptation in humans''' is an instance of [[evolutionary adaptation|evolutionary modification]] in certain human populations, including those of [[Tibetan people|Tibet]] in Asia, the [[Andes]] of the Americas, and [[People of Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] in Africa, who have acquired the ability to survive at extremely high [[altitudes]]. This adaptation means irreversible, [[adaptive evolution|long-term physiological responses]] to high-altitude environments, associated with heritable [[ethology|behavioural]] and [[mutation|genetic changes]].
While the rest of the human population would suffer serious health consequences, the indigenous inhabitants of these regions thrive well in the highest parts of the world. These people have undergone extensive physiological and genetic changes, particularly in the regulatory systems of oxygen [[respiratory system|respiration]] and blood [[circulatory system|circulation]], when compared to the general lowland population.<ref name=fris>{{cite book|author=Frisancho AR|title=Human Adaptation and Accommodation|year=1993|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-K_SYHBo42MC&pg|pages=175–301 |isbn =0472095110|publisher=University of Michigan Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=Hillary Mayell |title=Three High-Altitude Peoples, Three Adaptations to Thin Air|date=24 February 2004 | url=http://news.nationalgeographic.co.in/news/2004/02/0224_040225_evolution.html |work=National Geographic News |publisher=National Geographic Society |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
This special [[adaptation]] is now recognised as an example of [[natural selection]] in action.<ref name=bigh>{{cite journal|author=Bigham A, Bauchet M, Pinto D, Mao X, Akey JM, Mei R, Scherer SW, Julian CG, Wilson MJ, López Herráez D, Brutsaert T, Parra EJ, Moore LG, Shriver MD |year=2010 |title=Identifying signatures of natural selection in Tibetan and Andean populations using dense genome scan data | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1001116 |journal=PLOS Genetics |volume=6 |issue=9|pages=e1001116|pmid=20838600 |pmc=2936536 |doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1001116|last2=Bauchet |last3=Pinto |last4=Mao |last5=Akey |last6=Mei |last7=Scherer |last8=Julian |last9=Wilson |last10=López Herráez |last11=Brutsaert |last12=Parra |last13=Moore |last14=Shriver }}</ref> The adaptation account of the Tibetans has become the fastest case of [[human evolution]] in the scientific record, as it is estimated to have occurred in less than 3,000 years.<ref>{{cite web|author =Sanders R |title=Tibetans adapted to high altitude in less than 3,000 years|url=http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2010/07/01/tibetan_genome/ | date=1 July 2010 |work=News Centre, UC Berkeley |publisher=UC Regents|accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author =Hsu J |title=Tibetans Underwent Fastest Evolution Seen in Humans |url=http://www.livescience.com/6663-tibetans-underwent-fastest-evolution-humans.html | date=1 July 2010| work=Live Science | publisher=TechMediaNetwork.com| accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref name=yi>{{cite journal |last1=Yi |first1=X. |last2=Liang|first2=Y. |last3=Huerta-Sanchez |first3=E. |last4=Jin |first4=X. |last5=Cuo |first5=Z. X. P. |last6=Pool |first6=J. E. |last7=Xu |first7=X. |last8=Jiang |first8=H. |last9=Vinckenbosch |first9=N. |last10=Korneliussen |first10=T. S. |last11=Zheng |first11=H. |last12=Liu |first12=T. |last13=He |first13=W. |last14=Li |first14=K. |last15=Luo |first15=R. |last16=Nie |first16=X. |last17=Wu |first17=H. |last18=Zhao |first18=M. |last19=Cao |first19=H. |last20=Zou |first20=J. |last21=Shan |first21=Y. |last22=Li |first22=S. |last23=Yang |first23=Q. |last24=Asan |last25=Ni |first25=P. |last26=Tian |first26=G. |last27=Xu |first27=J. |last28=Liu |first28=X. |last29=Jiang |first29=T. |last30=Wu |first30=R. |last31=Zhou |first31=G. |last32=Tang |first32=M. |last33=Qin |first33=J. |last34=Wang |first34=T. |last35=Feng |first35=S. |last36=Li |first36=G. |last37=Huasang |last38=Luosang |first38=J. |last39=Wang |first39=W. |last40=Chen |first40=F. |last41=Wang |first41=Y. |last42=Zheng |first42=X. |last43=Li |first43=Z. |last44=Bianba |first44=Z. |last45=Yang|first45=G. |last46=Wang |first46=X. |last47=Tang|first47=S. |last48=Gao |first48=G. |last49=Chen|first49=Y. |last50=Luo |first50=Z. |last51=Gusang |first51=L. |last52=Cao |first52=Z. |last53=Zhang|first53=Q. |last54=Ouyang |first54=W. |last55=Ren |first55=X. |last56=Liang |first56=H. |last57=Zheng|first57=H. |last58=Huang|first58=Y. |last59=Li |first59=J. |last60=Bolund |first60=L. |last61=Kristiansen |first61=K. |last62=Li |first62=Y. |last63=Zhang |first63=Y. |last64=Zhang |first64=X. |last65=Li |first65=R. |last66=Li |first66=S. |last67=Yang |first67=H. |last68=Nielsen |first68=R. |last69=Wang |first69=J. |last70=Wang|first70=J. |title=Sequencing of 50 human exomes reveals adaptation to high altitude |journal=Science |year=2010 |volume=329 |issue=5987 |pages=75–78 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5987/75 |pmid=20595611 |pmc=3711608 |doi=10.1126/science.1190371 |displayauthors=8 |bibcode=2010Sci...329...75Y}}</ref>
Modern humans [[Recent African origin of modern humans|dispersed from Africa less than 100,000 years ago]], and eventually colonized the rest of the world,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Templeton, A. R. |year=2002|url=http://www.bioguider.com/ebook/biology/pdf/Templeton_n2002.pdf |title=Out of Africa again and again |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=416 |pages=45–51 |doi=10.1038/416045a |issue=6876}}</ref> including the harshest environments of extreme [[polar climate|cold]] and [[alpine climate|high mountains]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jeong|first1=Choongwon |last2=Di Rienzo |first2=Anna|title=Adaptations to local environments in modern human populations |journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development |year=2014 |volume=29 |pages=1–8 |doi=10.1016/j.gde.2014.06.011 |pmid=25129844 |pmc=4258478}}</ref> The abundance of [[oxygen]] in the [[atmosphere]] is inversely related to [[altitude]] from the [[sea level]]; hence, the highest mountain ranges of the world are considered unsuitable for human habitation.
Nevertheless, around 140 million people, just under 2% of the world's human population, live permanently at high [[altitude]]s, that is, at heights above {{convert|2,500|m|ft}} in [[South America]], [[East Africa]], and [[South Asia]]. These populations have done so for [[millennium|millennia]] without apparent complications.<ref name=moor>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG |year=1983 |title=Human genetic adaptation to high altitude| url=http://anthro.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441?requestedContent=related& |journal=High Altitude Medical Biology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=257–279 |pmid=11443005 |doi=10.1089/152702901750265341}}</ref> The overwhelming majority, over 98% of humans from other parts of the world, normally suffer symptoms of [[altitude sickness]] in these regions, often resulting in life-threatening [[Major trauma|trauma]] and even death.
Studies on the detail biological mechanism have revealed that adaptation of the Tibetans, Andeans and Ethiopians is indeed an observable instance of the process of natural selection in acting on [[fitness (biology)|favourable characters]] such as enhanced [[respiratory system|respiratory mechanisms]] in humans.<ref name=mue>{{cite book|author =Muehlenbein, MP |year=2010 |title=Human Evolutionary Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1VXX1jkhPH8C&pg|publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK |pages=170–191 |isbn=0521879485}}</ref><ref name=bea07>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM |year=2007|title=Detecting natural selection in high-altitude human populations | journal=Respir Physiol Neurobiol |volume=158|issue=2–3|pages=161–171 |pmid=17644049 |doi=10.1016/j.resp.2007.05.013 }}</ref>
==Origin and basis== [[File:Himalayas-Lhasa15.JPG|thumb|upright|Himalayas, on the southern rim of the Tibetan Plateau]]
[[Homo sapiens|Humans]] are naturally adapted to [[lowland]] environment where oxygen is abundant.<ref name=moo>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG, Regensteine JG|year=1983 |pmid=|title=Adaptation to High Altitude| url=http://anthro.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441?requestedContent=related& |journal=Annual Review of Anthropology |volume=12 |pages=285–304 |doi=10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441 |last2=Regensteiner }}</ref> When people from the general lowlands go to altitudes above {{convert|2,500|m|ft}}, with atmospheric pressure 74% of normal<ref>[https://www.mide.com/pages/air-pressure-at-altitude-calculator Air pressure at altitude calculator]</ref>{{cn|date=May 2018}} they experience [[altitude sickness|mountain sickness]], which is a type of [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], a clinical syndrome of severe lack of oxygen. Complications include [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[dizziness]], [[breathlessness]], [[headaches]], [[insomnia]], [[malaise]], [[nausea]], [[vomiting]], [[cramp|body pain]], [[Anorexia (symptom)|loss of appetite]], [[Tinnitus|ear-ringing]], [[frost bite|blistering]] and [[cyanosis|purpling of the hands and feet]], and [[vasodilation|dilated veins]].<ref name=pen>{{cite journal |author=Penaloza D, Arias-Stella J| title=The heart and pulmonary circulation at high altitudes: healthy highlanders and chronic mountain sickness |journal=Circulation |volume=115 |issue=9 |pages=1132–1146|year=2007 |url=http://circ.ahajournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17339571 |pmid=17339571 |doi=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.106.624544| last2=Arias-Stella }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=León-Velarde F, Villafuerte FC, Richalet JP | title=Chronic mountain sickness and the heart |journal=Prog Cardiovasc Dis |volume=52 | issue=6 |pages=540–549 |year=2010 |doi=10.1016/j.pcad.2010.02.012 |pmid=20417348| last2=Villafuerte | last3=Richalet }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Wheatley K, Creed M, Mellor A | title=Haematological changes at altitude |journal=J R Army Med Corps|volume=157 | issue=1 |pages=38–42 |year=2011 |doi=10.1136/jramc-157-01-07|pmid=21465909| last2=Creed | last3=Mellor }}</ref>
The sickness is compounded by related symptoms such as [[high altitude cerebral edema|cerebral oedema (swelling of brain)]] and [[high altitude pulmonary edema|pulmonary oedema (fluid accumulation in lungs)]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Paralikar SJ| title=High altitude pulmonary edema-clinical features, pathophysiology, prevention and treatment |journal=Indian J Occup Environ Med |volume=16| issue=2|pages=59–62 |year=2012|doi=10.4103/0019-5278.107066 |pmid=23580834| pmc=3617508 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Eide RP 3rd, Asplund CA | title=Altitude illness: update on prevention and treatment |journal=Curr Sports Med Rep |volume=11| issue=3|pages=124–30 |year=2012 |doi=10.1249/JSR.0b013e3182563e7a |pmid=22580489 | last2=Asplund }}</ref> For several days, they [[hyperventilation|breathe excessively]] and [[hypermetabolism|burn extra energy]] even when the body is [[basal metabolic rate|relaxed]]. The [[heart rate]] then gradually decreases. Hypoxia, in fact, is one of the principal causes of death among mountaineers.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Huey RB, Eguskitza X, Dillon M| title=Mountaineering in thin air. Patterns of death and of weather at high altitude |journal=Adv Exp Med Biol |volume=502 |issue=|pages=225–336|year=2001 |pmid=11950141 |doi=| last2=Eguskitza | last3=Dillon }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Firth PG, Zheng H, Windsor JS, Sutherland AI, Imray CH, Moore GW, Semple JL, Roach RC, Salisbury RA| title=Mortality on Mount Everest, 1921-2006: descriptive study |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=337|issue=|pages=a2654|year=2008 |pmid=19074222 |pmc=2602730 |doi=10.1136/bmj.a2654| last2=Zheng | last3=Windsor | last4=Sutherland | last5=Imray | last6=Moore | last7=Semple | last8=Roach | last9=Salisbury }}</ref> In women, pregnancy can be severely affected, such as development of [[hypertension|high blood pressure]], called [[preeclampsia]], which causes [[preterm birth|premature labour]], [[low birth weight]] of babies, and often [[complications of pregnancy|complicated]] with [[haemorrhage|profuse bleeding]], [[seizures]], and [[maternal death|death of the mother]].<ref name=fris /><ref>{{cite journal |author=Moore LG, Shriver M, Bemis L, Hickler B, Wilson M, Brutsaert T, Parra E, Vargas E| title=Maternal adaptation to high altitude pregnancy An experiment of nature A review |journal=Placenta |volume=25 |issue=suppl | pages=S60–S71 |year=2004 |doi=10.1016/j.placenta.2004.01.008| last2=Shriver | last3=Bemis | last4=Hickler | last5=Wilson | last6=Brutsaert | last7=Parra | last8=Vargas | pmid=15033310}}</ref>
More than 140 million people worldwide are estimated to live at an elevation higher than {{convert|2500|m|ft}} above sea level, of which 13 million are in Ethiopia, 1.7 million in Tibet (total of 78 million in [[Asia]]), 35 million in the South American Andes, and 0.3 million in [[Colorado]] [[Rocky Mountains]].<ref name=hor>{{cite book|vauthors=Hornbein T, Schoene R |year=2001|title=High Altitude: An Exploration of Human Adaptation (Lung Biology in Health and Disease Volume 161)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P1clQRmZk1AC&printsec |publisher=Marcel Dekker, New York, USA |pages=42–874 |isbn=082474604X}}</ref> Certain natives of Tibet, Ethiopia, and the Andes have been living at these high altitudes for generations and are protected from hypoxia as a consequence of genetic adaptation.<ref name=moor/><ref name=pen /> It is estimated that at {{convert|4000|m|ft}}, every [[lung volumes|lungful of air]] only has 60% of the oxygen molecules that people at sea level have.<ref name=hor /> At elevations above {{convert|7600|m|ft}}, [[hypoxia (medical)|lack of oxygen]] becomes seriously lethal. That is, these highlanders are constantly exposed to an intolerably low oxygen environment, yet they live without any debilitating problems.<ref name=mue/> Basically, the shared adaptation is the ability to maintain relatively low levels of [[haemoglobin]], which is the [[protein|chemical complex]] for [[circulatory system|transporting oxygen in the blood]].<ref name=moo /> One of the best documented effects of high altitude is a progressive reduction in [[birth weight]]. It has been known that women of long-resident high-altitude population are not affected. These women are known to give birth to heavier-weight infants than women of lowland inhabitants. This is particularly true among Tibetan babies, whose average birth weight is 294-650 (~470) g heavier than the surrounding [[chinese people|Chinese population]]; and their [[oxygen saturation|blood-oxygen level]] is considerably higher.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Niermeyer S, Yang P, Shanmina, Drolkar, Zhuang J, Moore LG|year=1995 |title=Arterial oxygen saturation in Tibetan and Han infants born in Lhasa, Tibet| url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199511093331903 |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=333 |issue=9 |pages=1248–1252|pmid=7566001|doi=10.1056/NEJM199511093331903 }}</ref>
The first scientific investigations of high-altitude adaptation was done by [[A. Roberto Frisancho]] of the [[University of Michigan]] in the late 1960s among the [[Quechua people]] of Peru.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Frisancho AR |title=Human growth and pulmonary function of a high altitude Peruvian Quechua population |journal=Hum Biol |volume= 41|issue=3 | pages=365–379 |year=1969 |pmid=5372293|jstor=41435777 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Leonard WR |title=Contributions of A. Roberto Frisancho to human population biology: An introduction |journal=American Journal of Human Biology |volume=21 |issue=5 | pages=599–605 |year=2009 |pmid=19367580|doi=10.1002/ajhb.20916}}</ref> [[Paul T. Baker]], [[Pennsylvania State University|Penn State University]], (in the [http://anth.la.psu.edu/ Department of Anthropology]) also conducted a considerable amount of research into human adaptation to high altitudes, and mentored students who continued this research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/member-directory/deceased-members/58048.html|title=Paul Baker|last=http://www.nasonline.org|first=National Academy of Sciences -|website=www.nasonline.org|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> One of these students went on to conduct research on high altitude adaptation among the Tibetans in the early 1980s through to today, anthropologist [[Cynthia Beall]] of the [[Case Western Reserve University]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall C |title=Human adaptability studies at high altitude: Research designs and major concepts during fifty years of discovery |journal=Am J Hum Biol |volume=25|issue=2 | pages=141–147 |year=2013 |pmid=23349118 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22355}}</ref>
==Physiological basis==
===Tibetans=== [[File:Sherpa.jpg|200px|thumb|right| A Sherpa family]]
Scientists started to notice the extraordinary physical performance of Tibetans since the beginning of Himalayan climbing era in the early 20th century. The hypothesis of a possible evolutionary genetic adaptation makes sense.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wu T, Kayser B |title=High altitude adaptation in Tibetans |journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=7 |issue=3 | pages=193–208 |year=2006 |pmid=16978132 |doi=10.1089/ham.2006.7.193|last2=Kayser }}</ref> The [[Tibetan plateau]] has an average elevation of {{convert|4000|m|ft}} above sea level, and covering more than 2.5 million km, it is the highest and largest [[plateau]] in the world. In 1990, it was estimated that 4,594,188 Tibetans live on the plateau, with 53% living at an altitude over {{convert|3500|m|ft}}. Fairly large numbers (about 600,000) live at an altitude exceeding {{convert|4500|m|ft}} in the Chantong-Qingnan area.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Wu T|year=2001 |title=The Qinghai-Tibetan plateau: how high do Tibetans live?| journal=High Alt Med Biol|volume=2|issue=4 |pages=489–499|pmid=11809089 |doi=10.1089/152702901753397054}}</ref> Where the Tibetan highlanders live, the oxygen level is only about 60% of that at sea level. The Tibetans, who have been living in this region for 3,000 years, do not exhibit the elevated haemoglobin concentrations to cope with oxygen deficiency as observed in other populations who have moved temporarily or permanently at high altitudes. Instead, the Tibetans inhale more air with each breath and breathe more rapidly than either sea-level populations or Andeans. Tibetans have better [[oxygenation (medical)|oxygenation]] at birth, enlarged lung volumes throughout life, and a higher capacity for [[physical exercise|exercise]]. They show a sustained increase in [[brain|cerebral]] blood flow, lower haemoglobin concentration, and less susceptibility to [[chronic mountain sickness]] than other populations, due to their longer history of high-altitude habitation.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG, Niermeyer S, Zamudio S |year=1998 |title=Human adaptation to high altitude: Regional and life-cycle perspectives |journal=Am J Phys Anthropol |volume=107 |pages=25–64 |pmid=9881522 | doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(1998)107:27+<25::AID-AJPA3>3.0.CO;2-L |last2=Niermeyer |last3=Zamudio}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Lorna G|last=Moore |year=2001 |title=Human genetic adaptation to high altitude|journal=High Altitude Medicine & Biology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=257–279 |pmid=11443005| doi=10.1089/152702901750265341}}</ref>
General people can develop short-term tolerance with careful physical preparation and systematic monitoring of movements, but the biological changes are quite temporary and reversible when they return to lowlands.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Muza SR, Beidleman BA, Fulco CS|year=2010 |title=Altitude preexposure recommendations for inducing acclimatization| journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=11|issue=2|pages=87–92|pmid=20586592 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1006 |last2=Beidleman |last3=Fulco }}</ref> Moreover, unlike lowland people who only experience [[hyperventilation|increased breathing]] for a few days after entering high altitudes, Tibetans retain this rapid breathing and elevated lung-capacity throughout their lifetime.<ref name=beall07>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM |year=2007 |title=Two routes to functional adaptation: Tibetan and Andean high-altitude natives | journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A|volume=14|issue=Suppl 1 |pages=8655–8660|pmid=17494744 |pmc=1876443 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0701985104|bibcode=2007PNAS..104.8655B }}</ref> This enables them to inhale larger amounts of air per unit of time to compensate for low oxygen levels. In addition, they have high levels (mostly double) of [[nitric oxide]] in their blood, when compared to lowlanders, and this probably helps their blood vessels [[vasodilation|dilate]] for enhanced [[blood circulation]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM, Laskowski D, Erzurum SC|year=2012 |title=Nitric oxide in adaptation to altitude |journal=Free Radic Biol Med |volume=52 |issue=7 |pages=1123–1134 |pmid=22300645 |pmc=3295887 |doi=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2011.12.028|last2=Laskowski |last3=Erzurum }}</ref> Further, their haemoglobin level is not significantly different (average 15.6 g/dl in males and 14.2 g/dl in females),<ref name=beall1998>{{cite journal|last1=Beall|first1=Cynthia M.|last2=Brittenham|first2=Gary M.|last3=Strohl|first3=Kingman P.|last4=Blangero|first4=John|last5=Williams-Blangero|first5=Sarah|last6=Goldstein|first6=Melvyn C.|last7=Decker|first7=Michael J.|last8=Vargas|first8=Enrique|last9=Villena|first9=Mercedes|last10=Soria|first10=Rudy|last11=Alarcon|first11=Ana Maria|last12=Gonzales|first12=Cristina|display-authors=8|title=Hemoglobin concentration of high-altitude Tibetans and Bolivian Aymara|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|date=1998|volume=106|issue=3|pages=385–400|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(199807)106:3<385::AID-AJPA10>3.0.CO;2-X|pmid=9696153}}</ref> from those of people living at low altitude. (Normally, mountaineers experience >2 g/dl increase in Hb level at Mt. Everest base camp in two weeks.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Windsor|first1=J. S|last2=Rodway|first2=G. W |title=Heights and haematology: the story of haemoglobin at altitude |journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal |date=2007 |volume=83 |issue=977 |pages=148–151 |doi=10.1136/pgmj.2006.049734 |pmid=17344565 |pmc=2599997}}</ref>) In this way they are able to evade both the effects of hypoxia and mountain sickness throughout life. Even when they climbed the highest summits like Mt. Everest, they showed regular oxygen uptake, greater ventilation, more brisk hypoxic ventilatory responses, larger lung volumes, greater diffusing capacities, constant body weight and a better quality of sleep, compared to people from the lowland.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wu T, Li S, Ward MP |year=2005 |title=Tibetans at extreme altitude| journal=Wilderness Environ Med |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=47–54 |pmid=15813148 |doi=10.1580/pr04-04.1|last2=Li |last3=Ward }}</ref>
===Andeans===
In contrast to the Tibetans, the Andean highlanders, who have been living at high-altitudes for no more than 11,000 years, show different pattern of haemoglobin adaptation. Their haemoglobin concentration is higher compared to those of lowlander population, which also happens to lowlanders moving to high altitude. When they spend some weeks in the lowland their haemoglobin drops to average of other people. This shows only temporary and reversible acclimatisation. However, in contrast to lowland people, they do have increased oxygen level in their haemoglobin, that is, more oxygen per blood volume than other people. This confers an ability to carry more oxygen in each red blood cell, making a more effective transport of oxygen in their body, while their breathing is essentially at the same rate.<ref name=beall07 /> This enables them to overcome hypoxia and normally reproduce without risk of death for the mother or baby. The Andean highlanders are known from the 16th-century missionaries that their reproduction had always been normal, without any effect in the [[fecundity|giving birth]] or the risk for early pregnancy loss, which are common to hypoxic stress.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vitzthum |first1=Virginia J. |title=Fifty fertile years: anthropologists' studies of reproduction in high altitude natives |journal=American Journal of Human Biology |year=2013 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=179–189 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22357 |pmid=23382088}}</ref> They have developmentally acquired enlarged residual lung volume and its associated increase in [[alveolus|alveolar]] area, which are supplemented with increased tissue thickness and moderate increase in [[red blood cells]]. Though the physical growth in body size is [[stunted growth|delayed]], growth in lung volumes is accelerated.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Frisancho|first1=A. Roberto|title=Developmental functional adaptation to high altitude: review|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|date=2013|volume=25|issue=2|pages=151–168|doi=10.1002/ajhb.22367|pmid=24065360}}</ref> An incomplete adaptation such as elevated haemoglobin levels still leaves them at risk for mountain sickness with old age. oxide synthase]], eNOS), which is associated with higher levels of nitric oxide in high altitude.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wang|first1=Pei|last2=Ha|first2=Alice Y.N. |last3=Kidd|first3=Kenneth K. high altitude Native population|journal=High Altitude Medicine & Biology|year=2010|volume=11|issue=1|pages=27–30|doi=10.1089/ham.2009.1054|pmid=20367485}}</ref> Nuñoa children of Quechua ancestry exhibit higher blood-oxygen content (91.3) and lower heart rate (84.8) than their counterpart school children of different ethnicity, who have an average of 89.9 blood-oxygen and 88-91 heart adolescents living at high altitude| journal=Am J Hum Biol|volume=13 |issue=6 |pages=761–770|pmid=11748815 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.1122|last2=Pawson |last3=León-Velarde |last4=Rivera-Chira |last5=Pacheco For example, among four quantitative features, such as are resting ventilation, hypoxic ventilatory response, oxygen saturation, and haemoglobin concentration, the levels of variations are significantly different between the Tibetans and the Aymaras.<ref name=bea00>{{cite journal| author=Beall CM |year=2000 |title=Tibetan and Andean patterns of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia|journal=Hum Biol|volume=72 |issue=1 |pages=201–228 |pmid=10721618|doi=}}</ref> The Andeans, in general are the most poorly adapted, as particularly shown by their frequent mountain sickness and loss of adaptative characters when they move to lowlands.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Xing G, Qualls C, Huicho L, Rivera-Ch M, Stobdan T, Slessarev M, Prisman E, Ito S, Wu H, Norboo A, Dolma D, Kunzang M, Norboo T, Gamboa JL, Claydon VE, Fisher J, Zenebe G, Gebremedhin A, Hainsworth R, Verma A, Appenzeller O|year=2008 |title=Adaptation and mal-adaptation to ambient hypoxia; Andean, Ethiopian and Himalayan patterns|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0002342 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=3 |issue=6 |pages=e2342 |pmid=18523639 |pmc=2396283 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002342|last2=Qualls |last3=Huicho |last4=Rivera-Ch |last5=Stobdan |last6=Slessarev |last7=Prisman |last8=Ito |last9=Wu |last10=Norboo |last11=Dolma |last12=Kunzang |last13=Norboo |last14=Gamboa |last15=Claydon |last16=Fisher |last17=Zenebe |last18=Gebremedhin |last19=Hainsworth |last20=Verma |last21=Appenzeller |bibcode=2008PLoSO...3.2342X }}</ref>
===Ethiopians===
The peoples of the [[Ethiopian highlands]] also live at extremely high altitudes, around {{convert|3000|m|ft}} to {{convert|3500|m|ft}}. Highland Ethiopians exhibit elevated haemoglobin levels, like Andeans and lowlander peoples at high altitudes, but do not exhibit the Andean’s increased in oxygen-content of haemoglobin.<ref>{{cite journal| author =Beall CM |year=2006|title=Andean, Tibetan, and Ethiopian patterns of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Integr Comp Biol |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=18–24 |pmid=21672719 |doi=10.1093/icb/icj004}}</ref> Among healthy individuals, the average haemoglobin concentrations are 15.9 and 15.0 g/dl for males and females respectively (which is lower than normal, almost similar to the Tibetans), and an average oxygen saturation of haemoglobin is 95.3% (which is higher than average, like the Andeans).<ref>{{cite journal| author=Beall CM, Decker MJ, Brittenham GM, Kushner I, Gebremedhin A, Strohl KP |year=2002 |title=An Ethiopian pattern of human adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=99 |issue=26 |pages=17215–17218 |pmid=12471159 |pmc=139295 |doi=10.1073/pnas.252649199 |last2=Decker |last3=Brittenham |last4=Kushner |last5=Gebremedhin |last6=Strohl |bibcode=2002PNAS...9917215B}}</ref> Additionally, Ethiopian highlanders do not exhibit any significant change in blood circulation of the brain, which has been observed among the Peruvian highlanders (and attributed to their frequent altitude-related illnesses).<ref>{{cite journal| author=Claydon VE, Gulli G, Slessarev M, Appenzeller O, Zenebe G, Gebremedhin A, Hainsworth R |year=2008|title=Cerebrovascular responses to hypoxia and hypocapnia in Ethiopian high altitude dwellers |journal=Stroke |volume=39 |issue=2|pages=336–342 |pmid=18096845 |doi=10.1161/STROKEAHA.107.491498|last2=Gulli|last3=Slessarev|last4=Appenzeller|last5=Zenebe|last6=Gebremedhin|last7=Hainsworth}}</ref> Yet, similar to the Andeans and Tibetans, the Ethiopian highlanders are immune to the extreme dangers posed by high-altitude environment, and their pattern of adaptation is definitely unique from that of other highland peoples.<ref name=hor />
==Genetic basis==
The underlying [[molecular evolution]] of high-altitude adaptation has been explored and understood fairly recently.<ref name=mue /> Depending on the geographical and environmental pressures, high-altitude adaptation involves different genetic patterns, some of which have evolved quite recently. For example, Tibetan adaptations became prevalent in the past 3,000 years, a rapid example of [[recent human evolution]]. At the turn of the 21st century, it was reported that the genetic make-up of the respiratory components of the Tibetan and the Ethiopian populations are significantly different.<ref name=bea00 />
=== Tibetans ===
Substantial evidence in Tibetan highlanders suggests that variation in haemoglobin and [[oxygen saturation|blood-oxygen]] levels are adaptive as [[Fitness (biology)|Darwinian fitness]]. It has been documented that Tibetan women with a high likelihood of possessing one to two [[allele]]s for high blood-oxygen content (which is odd for normal women) had more surviving children; the higher the oxygen capacity, the lower the infant mortality.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall CM, Song K, Elston RC, Goldstein MC |year=2004 |title=Higher offspring survival among Tibetan women with high oxygen saturation genotypes residing at {{convert|4000|m|ft}}| url=http://www.pnas.org/content/101/39/14300 |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=101|issue=39 |pages=14300–14304 |pmid=15353580|pmc=521103 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0405949101|last2=Song |last3=Elston |last4=Goldstein |bibcode=2004PNAS..10114300B }}</ref> In 2010, for the first time, the genes responsible for the unique adaptive traits were identified following genome sequences of 50 Tibetans and 40 [[Han Chinese]] from [[Beijing]]. Initially, the strongest signal of natural selection detected was a transcription factor involved in response to hypoxia, called endothelial Per-Arnt-Sim (PAS) domain protein 1 (''[[EPAS1]]''). It was found that one [[single-nucleotide polymorphism]] (SNP) at ''EPAS1'' shows a 78% frequency difference between Tibetan and mainland Chinese samples, representing the fastest genetic change observed in any human gene to date. Hence, Tibetan adaptation to high altitude becomes the fastest process of [[phenotype|phenotypically observable]] evolution in humans,<ref>{{cite web|author1=Native Village Youth |author2=Education news |title=Tibetans evolved at fastest pace ever measured |url=http://www.nativevillage.org/Archives/2011%20Archives/MAY%202011%20News/Tibetans%20Evolved%20at%20Fastest%20Pace%20Ever%20Measured.htm | date=May 2011|accessdate=2013-04-15}}</ref> which is estimated to occur in less than 3,000 years ago, when the Tibetans split up from the mainland Chinese population.<ref name=yi /> [[Mutations]] in ''EPAS1'', at higher frequency in Tibetans than their Han neighbours, correlate with decreased haemoglobin concentrations among the Tibetans, which is the hallmark of their adaptation to hypoxia. Simultaneously, two genes, egl nine homolog 1 (''[[EGLN1]]'') (which inhibits haemoglobin production under high oxygen concentration) and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (''[[PPARA]]''), were also identified to be positively selected in relation to decreased haemoglobin nature in the Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Simonson TS, Yang Y, Huff CD, Yun H, Qin G, Witherspoon DJ, Bai Z, Lorenzo FR, Xing J, Jorde LB, Prchal JT, Ge R |year=2010 |title=Genetic evidence for high-altitude adaptation in Tibet | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5987/72 |journal=Science |volume=329 |issue=5987|pages=72–75 |pmid=20466884 |doi=10.1126/science.1189406|last2=Yang |last3=Huff |last4=Yun |last5=Qin |last6=Witherspoon |last7=Bai |last8=Lorenzo |last9=Xing |last10=Jorde |last11=Prchal |last12=Ge |bibcode=2010Sci...329...72S }}</ref>
Similarly, the [[Sherpas]], known for their Himalayan hardiness, exhibit similar patterns in the ''EPAS1'' gene, which further fortifies that the gene is under [[Selection (biology)|selection]] for adaptation to the high-altitude life of Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Hanaoka M, Droma Y, Basnyat B, Ito M, Kobayashi N, Katsuyama Y, Kubo K, Ota M |year=2012 |title=Genetic variants in EPAS1 contribute to adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia in Sherpas | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0050566 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=12|pages=e50566|pmid=23227185 indicates that the mutant ''[[EPAS1]]'' gene could have been inherited from archaic [[hominin]]s, the [[Denisovans]].<ref name="Huerta-Sanchez et al. 2014">{{cite journal |last6=Vinckenbosch|first6=Nicolas|last7=Liang|first7=Yu|last8=Yi|first8=Xin|last9=He|first9=Mingze|last10=Somel|first10=Mehmet|last11=Ni|first11=Peixiang|last12=Wang|first12=Bo|last13=Ou|first13=Xiaohua|last14=Huasang|last15=Luosang|first15=Jiangbai|last16=Cuo|first16=Zha |last24=Li |first24=Yingrui |last25=Wang |first25=Jian |last26=Wang |first26=Jun |last27=Nielsen |first27=Rasmus |title=Altitude adaptation in Tibetans caused by introgression of Denisovan-like DNA
